article.headline: McKenzie hits five 3s, scores 18 in win
article.linkText: McKenzie frenzy shoots Sooners past Huskers
article.story: LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) -- Lawrence McKenzie took it upon himself to finish what he started Sunday, and it was just in time for No. 25 Oklahoma. McKenzie's four 3-pointers in the first half helped the Sooners build a 17-point lead over Nebraska, but the Sooners found themselves down a point with 3:27 left. The freshman guard hit a free throw to tie it and then made the go-ahead 3 with 2:24 left to carry the Sooners to a 52-50 victory. "Everybody's mindset was to get the game over with," McKenzie said. "Nobody really looked to step up and shoot the ball. I decided I'd take a few shots and help the team out." McKenzie finished with 18 points and 10 rebounds for the Sooners (13-4, 3-3 Big 12), who scored just 16 points in the second half and went a stretch of 10:18 without scoring. The last 3-pointer was McKenzie's fifth to tie his career high and it was his first field goal since 2:22 left in the first half. "Lawrence played great today and kind of took us on his back at the start, and he definitely took it upon himself at the end," Oklahoma center Jabahri Brown said. Brian Conklin gave Nebraska a 45-44 lead with 3:28 left when he capped a 15-0 run by the Cornhuskers (11-6, 1-5). McKenzie's free throw with 3:08 left stopped the Sooners' drought. After Nebraska's Andrew Drevo missed underneath, McKenzie made his final 3 to put Oklahoma ahead for good. Jake Muhleisen scored 11 points for the Huskers and Conklin had 10. "It's tough because we were right there," Nebraska's Marcus Neal said. "They're ranked and we feel like we can play with anybody, but we just can't make enough plays to win the game." Oklahoma has won three straight since seeing its roster drop to nine players following Kevin Bookout's announcement that he will undergo season-ending shoulder surgery this week. Four of the nine players are freshmen and one is a sophomore. The Sooners, who came into the game 10th in the Big 12 and 255th nationally in 3-point shooting (32.0 percent), were 7-of-14 from long range in the first half in taking a 36-21 lead. McKenzie hit three 3s over Nebraska's zone defense in the first 4 minutes and scored 14 points in the first half. "When I hit the first shot, I'm going to test myself and see if I can make the next one," McKenzie said. "The next one was good, and the next one after that. I've got to credit my teammates for getting me the ball. I've never found myself as open as I was this game." Oklahoma's first two-point field goal, De'Angelo Alexander's putback with 12:11 left in the half, gave the Sooners a double-digit lead. Nebraska missed 13 of its first 15 shots and went a stretch of 9:48 without a field goal. But midway through the second half, Nate Johnson drove the length of the floor for a layup to start the Huskers' 15-0 run. "Oklahoma played great defense in the first half, and we weren't the aggressor," Nebraska coach Barry Collier said. "It was an about-face in the second half. Our guys just had more determination." Brown said the Sooners got too comfortable after taking the big first-half lead. "We let up, eased up, and they made a huge run," he said. Oklahoma coach Kelvin Sampson said he thought his team did a good job defensively all day and got good looks at the basket even during the long scoring drought. "It's amazing when you're on the road and you have a big lead," Sampson said. "Every time the other team gets a shot, it goes in. It looked like from my vantage point that Nebraska didn't miss a shot in the second half. The first half, it didn't look like they could make one." The Sooners went 12 possessions without a field goal from the 13:26 mark until McKenzie's tie-breaking 3. "Those are the shots I practice on, and Coach tells us to come out and shoot with confidence, and that's what I did," McKenzie said.
